content.description:
An older route in need of a name.  A run in with a LARGE, HAIRY and SPIKE covered bug near the top in the crack seemed like a good namesake. 

  Follow bolts up and slightly left.  Near the top, in a shallow corner, follow a crack and blocky rock up to the anchor.
content.protection:
Glue In Bolts

 Steel Biners for lowering.
content.location: The last route on the right side of OT before the prominent break right near the large trees at the base.

content.description:
Fun flake and Pocket pulling leads to a fun little crux surmounting the upper bulge on the arete. 

 Scramble up the lower angle rock to clip the first bolt. Pull up onto the lower ledge.   Move slightly left and up, aiming for a left slanting flake (watch for PI in there).  Climb through the flake and up into fun pockets on the rounded bulge. Continue up on the bulge aiming to the right of the massive hole below the steep, grey headwall.  Reaching the headwall, move up and right surmounting the headwall and arete to finish on the large upper ledge.
content.protection:
Bolts for Pro 

  Anchor with SS Biners for lowering.

content.description:
With the complete re-bolt of MedWall this is the re-aligned old bottom section of Sleep Deprivation following a better line slightly right.

 Start as for SD to the first ledge.  Take the right bolt line straight up on horizontal, blocky holds through fun, vertical moves.  Continue up into large pockets to finish at a mid-anchor below the corner.

Located on the far left side of the main OT wall.  Follow ramps and corners past bolts to a high anchor. 

  Start on the far left of OT at the base.  Scramble up the low angle rock trending left to a small arete and the first bolt.  Climb up on the left and follow the slab past another bolt up the base of the steeper rock on the far left.  Pull over the bulge and into the base of a left facing corner.  Follow this up past more bolts until you can pull onto the ledge.  You'll pull past one more bulge and continue up easier climbing to the anchor.  Mussy Hooks to lower.
content.protection:
Bolts for pro 

  Mussy Hook Anchors

content.description:
Pocket Pulling through the steep middle part of the OT bulge.

 A variation breeching the steep headwall left of Sleep Deprivation.

 For the most "new" climbing, start as for Sleep Deprivation. After the flake, trend leftwards aiming LEFT of the huge hole.  Climb the main headwall pulling on small pockets staying on the right side.  Pull the lip to anchors on the main upper ledge.
content.protection:
4 Glue Ins through the Bulge. 

  Shares anchors with other routes on the ledge.

content.description: This climb starts near the far left side of OT left of the stepped ramps. Start off the base trail and head straight up aiming for a right facing corner above. After making a few easy moves, pull up onto steeper rock and continue up right of the large crack formed by some blocky rock on the left. Continue up past the small tree onto the “Balcony”. Dew Point continues off the far right side of the balcony in front of the larger tree right of the cave. Pull up onto the headwall on large holes skirting the right side of the cave. Now, move up and left onto sold rock above the hole. Pull the crux moves on the face aiming more or less straight up towards the roof above. At the base of the roof, slight left and then up to the anchor. Note, you can clip the lower anchor bolt as a lead bolt and then the second Mussy Hook when you reach the anchor. There were two old bolts on the upper section, almost as a variation to Old 5.7. There were no anchors above nor lower bolts so we never could figure out what their story was. So upper DP could be restored old climb or just taking nearby line past abandoned bolts.
content.protection: Glue in bolts. Lower off anchor.
content.location: Far left side of OT starting off the base trail as it starts into the woods heading towards Med School.

content.description:
THE classic at OT.  Fun moves on good (for the most part) rock to the top of the wall. 

  Follow a mixture of hangers and glue ins up the left side of the "swiss cheese" bulge to a ledge.  Lower or continue up more broken terrain to the top of the wall.
content.protection: BOLTS -  A Mixture of Wedges and Glue Ins.   Chains at the mid-ledge and at the top for rap or lowering.

content.description:
One of the original "old routes" with an unknown name, Bermuda Triangles used to go all the way to the top of the wall over two small triangle-like blocks.  Those blocks and a large section of the upper corner gave way to gravity last fall (see orange rock scar) and with the missing triangles came a route name.  Recently restored with two bolts so it again goes to the top of the wall. 

  Head up through the small notch at the base past one bolt onto the lower ledge.  Climb straight up past more bolts though pockets and blocky holds eventually heading up the ramp to the base of the left facing corner and corner crack.  Climb the corner and crack past one bolt to anchors on the left at the upper ledge. Lower/Rap or continue up past two more bolts staying left and out of the orange corner. Watch out for loose rock near the top.  It's got a more alpine feel but remains fun as you "get up high" on the wall. Chains at the top.
content.protection: 12 Bolts for Pro.Upper Anchor Has Steel Lower Offs
content.location: On the right side of OT.

content.description: Start left of the classic TX Caterpillar.  Fun moves to the first stance.  Make moves over the bulge trending left slightly past a hole (watch the Cat Claw) and then trend up and right climbing the steep face until you reach the next ledge.  Make the final moves over the steep bulge through the V notch to lower angle rock and the anchor above.
content.location: Named for the HUGE hanging block that used to sit atop the upper ledge.  It was sent down to remove the hazard, hence the name.

content.description:
6/19/20 - OT is back!  Please use the photo topo for the best info right now.  Descriptions, routes etc will be updated as time allows.

 The Tallest Wall found at the "Med". The upper section is a bit chossy so be careful. The lower tier has some good rock on it.
